title: Trigonometric Differentiation - Formulas MCQ
subtitle: NIOS Class 12 Mathematics - Derivatives of Trigonometric Functions

questions.question: What is d/dx(sin x)?
questions.explanation: The derivative of sine is cosine: d/dx(sin x) = cos x. This is one of the fundamental trigonometric derivatives.

questions.question: What is d/dx(cos x)?
questions.explanation: The derivative of cosine is negative sine: d/dx(cos x) = -sin x.

questions.question: What is d/dx(tan x)?
questions.explanation: The derivative of tangent: d/dx(tan x) = sec² x. This can be derived using the quotient rule on sin x/cos x.

questions.question: What is d/dx(cot x)?
questions.explanation: The derivative of cotangent: d/dx(cot x) = -cosec² x or -csc² x.

questions.question: What is d/dx(sec x)?
questions.explanation: The derivative of secant: d/dx(sec x) = sec x tan x. This can be derived from d/dx(1/cos x).

questions.question: What is d/dx(cosec x)?
questions.explanation: The derivative of cosecant: d/dx(cosec x) = -cosec x cot x or d/dx(csc x) = -csc x cot x.

questions.question: What is d/dx(sin⁻¹ x)?
questions.explanation: The derivative of inverse sine (arcsin): d/dx(sin⁻¹ x) = 1/√(1-x²) for -1 < x < 1.

questions.question: What is d/dx(cos⁻¹ x)?
questions.explanation: The derivative of inverse cosine (arccos): d/dx(cos⁻¹ x) = -1/√(1-x²) for -1 < x < 1.

questions.question: What is d/dx(tan⁻¹ x)?
questions.explanation: The derivative of inverse tangent (arctan): d/dx(tan⁻¹ x) = 1/(1+x²) for all real x.

questions.question: What is d/dx(cot⁻¹ x)?
questions.explanation: The derivative of inverse cotangent (arccot): d/dx(cot⁻¹ x) = -1/(1+x²) for all real x.

questions.question: What is d/dx(sec⁻¹ x)?
questions.explanation: The derivative of inverse secant (arcsec): d/dx(sec⁻¹ x) = 1/(|x|√(x²-1)) for |x| > 1.

questions.question: What is d/dx(cosec⁻¹ x)?
questions.explanation: The derivative of inverse cosecant (arccsc): d/dx(cosec⁻¹ x) = -1/(|x|√(x²-1)) for |x| > 1.

questions.question: What is d/dx(sin 2x)?
questions.explanation: Using chain rule: d/dx(sin 2x) = cos 2x × d/dx(2x) = cos 2x × 2 = 2cos 2x.

questions.question: What is d/dx(cos 3x)?
questions.explanation: Using chain rule: d/dx(cos 3x) = -sin 3x × d/dx(3x) = -sin 3x × 3 = -3sin 3x.

questions.question: What is d/dx(tan(ax)) where a is constant?
questions.explanation: Using chain rule: d/dx(tan(ax)) = sec²(ax) × d/dx(ax) = sec²(ax) × a = a sec²(ax).

questions.question: What is d/dx(sin² x)?
questions.explanation: Using chain rule: d/dx(sin² x) = 2sin x × d/dx(sin x) = 2sin x × cos x = 2sin x cos x = sin 2x. Options B and C are equivalent.

questions.question: What is d/dx(cos² x)?
questions.explanation: Using chain rule: d/dx(cos² x) = 2cos x × d/dx(cos x) = 2cos x × (-sin x) = -2cos x sin x = -sin 2x. Options A and C are equivalent.

questions.question: What is d/dx(tan² x)?
questions.explanation: Using chain rule: d/dx(tan² x) = 2tan x × d/dx(tan x) = 2tan x × sec² x = 2tan x sec² x.

questions.question: What is d/dx(√sin x)?
questions.explanation: Rewrite as (sin x)^(1/2). Chain rule: d/dx[(sin x)^(1/2)] = (1/2)(sin x)^(-1/2) × cos x = cos x/(2√sin x).

questions.question: What is d/dx(e^(sin x))?
questions.explanation: Using chain rule: d/dx(e^(sin x)) = e^(sin x) × d/dx(sin x) = e^(sin x) × cos x = e^(sin x) cos x.

questions.question: What is d/dx(ln(sin x))?
questions.explanation: Using chain rule: d/dx(ln(sin x)) = (1/sin x) × d/dx(sin x) = (1/sin x) × cos x = cos x/sin x = cot x. Options B and C are equivalent.

questions.question: What is d/dx(ln(cos x))?
questions.explanation: Using chain rule: d/dx(ln(cos x)) = (1/cos x) × d/dx(cos x) = (1/cos x) × (-sin x) = -sin x/cos x = -tan x. Options B and C are equivalent.

questions.question: What is d/dx(sin(x²))?
questions.explanation: Using chain rule: d/dx(sin(x²)) = cos(x²) × d/dx(x²) = cos(x²) × 2x = 2x cos(x²).

questions.question: What is d/dx(cos(1/x))?
questions.explanation: Using chain rule: d/dx(cos(1/x)) = -sin(1/x) × d/dx(1/x) = -sin(1/x) × (-1/x²) = sin(1/x)/x². Wait, this equals option A. Let me recalculate: -sin(1/x) × (-1/x²) = sin(1/x)/x². The correct answer should be A, but given the options, it's actually sin(1/x)/x² which is positive.

questions.question: What is d/dx(x sin x)?
questions.explanation: Using product rule: d/dx(x sin x) = x × d/dx(sin x) + sin x × d/dx(x) = x cos x + sin x = sin x + x cos x.

questions.question: What is d/dx(x² cos x)?
questions.explanation: Using product rule: d/dx(x² cos x) = x² × d/dx(cos x) + cos x × d/dx(x²) = x²(-sin x) + cos x(2x) = 2x cos x - x² sin x.

questions.question: What is d/dx(sin x/x)?
questions.explanation: Using quotient rule: d/dx(sin x/x) = (x × cos x - sin x × 1)/x² = (x cos x - sin x)/x².

questions.question: What is d/dx(tan x - x)?
questions.explanation: d/dx(tan x - x) = d/dx(tan x) - d/dx(x) = sec² x - 1. Note: sec² x - 1 = tan² x, so options B and C are equivalent.

questions.question: What is d/dx(sec² x)?
questions.explanation: Using chain rule: d/dx(sec² x) = 2sec x × d/dx(sec x) = 2sec x × (sec x tan x) = 2sec² x tan x.

questions.question: What is d/dx(cosec² x)?
questions.explanation: Using chain rule: d/dx(cosec² x) = 2cosec x × d/dx(cosec x) = 2cosec x × (-cosec x cot x) = -2cosec² x cot x.

questions.question: What is d/dx(sin(ln x))?
questions.explanation: Using chain rule: d/dx(sin(ln x)) = cos(ln x) × d/dx(ln x) = cos(ln x) × (1/x) = cos(ln x)/x.

questions.question: What is d/dx(cos(e^x))?
questions.explanation: Using chain rule: d/dx(cos(e^x)) = -sin(e^x) × d/dx(e^x) = -sin(e^x) × e^x = -e^x sin(e^x).

questions.question: What is d/dx(tan⁻¹(2x))?
questions.explanation: Using chain rule: d/dx(tan⁻¹(2x)) = 1/(1+(2x)²) × d/dx(2x) = 1/(1+4x²) × 2 = 2/(1+4x²).

questions.question: What is d/dx(e^x sin x)?
questions.explanation: Using product rule: d/dx(e^x sin x) = e^x × sin x + e^x × cos x = e^x(sin x + cos x).

questions.question: What is d/dx(e^x cos x)?
questions.explanation: Using product rule: d/dx(e^x cos x) = e^x × cos x + e^x × (-sin x) = e^x(cos x - sin x).

questions.question: What is d/dx(sin³ x)?
questions.explanation: Using chain rule: d/dx(sin³ x) = 3sin² x × d/dx(sin x) = 3sin² x × cos x = 3sin² x cos x.

questions.question: What is d/dx(cos³ x)?
questions.explanation: Using chain rule: d/dx(cos³ x) = 3cos² x × d/dx(cos x) = 3cos² x × (-sin x) = -3cos² x sin x.

questions.question: What is d/dx(sin x cos x)?
questions.explanation: Using product rule: d/dx(sin x cos x) = sin x(-sin x) + cos x(cos x) = cos² x - sin² x = cos 2x. Options A and C are equivalent.

questions.question: What is d/dx(1/sin x)?
questions.explanation: d/dx(cosec x) = -cosec x cot x or using quotient rule: d/dx(1/sin x) = (0 - cos x)/sin² x = -cos x/sin² x = -(cos x/sin x)(1/sin x) = -cot x cosec x. Options A, C, and D are all equivalent.

questions.question: What is d/dx(1/cos x)?
questions.explanation: d/dx(sec x) = sec x tan x. Using quotient rule: d/dx(1/cos x) = sin x/cos² x = (sin x/cos x)(1/cos x) = tan x sec x. Options A, B, and C are equivalent.

questions.question: What is d/dx(tan⁻¹(sin x))?
questions.explanation: Using chain rule: d/dx(tan⁻¹(sin x)) = 1/(1+sin² x) × d/dx(sin x) = 1/(1+sin² x) × cos x = cos x/(1+sin² x).

questions.question: What is d/dx(sin⁻¹(cos x))?
questions.explanation: Using chain rule and noting that √(1-cos² x) = |sin x|: d/dx(sin⁻¹(cos x)) = 1/√(1-cos² x) × (-sin x) = -sin x/|sin x| = -1 for 0 < x < π.

questions.question: What is d/dx(x tan x)?
questions.explanation: Using product rule: d/dx(x tan x) = x × d/dx(tan x) + tan x × d/dx(x) = x sec² x + tan x = tan x + x sec² x.

questions.question: What is d/dx(cot x + tan x)?
questions.explanation: d/dx(cot x + tan x) = d/dx(cot x) + d/dx(tan x) = -cosec² x + sec² x = sec² x - cosec² x. Options A and B are equivalent.

questions.question: What is d/dx(sin(2sin x))?
questions.explanation: Using chain rule twice: d/dx(sin(2sin x)) = cos(2sin x) × d/dx(2sin x) = cos(2sin x) × 2cos x = 2cos x cos(2sin x).

questions.question: What is d/dx(cos⁻¹(1-x²))?
questions.explanation: Using chain rule: d/dx(cos⁻¹(1-x²)) = -1/√(1-(1-x²)²) × (-2x) = 2x/√(1-(1-2x²+x⁴)) = 2x/√(2x²-x⁴). Wait, actually it should be negative: -1/√... × (-2x) = 2x/√... But simplifying the radical: √(1-1+2x²-x⁴) = √(2x²-x⁴). The negative from the derivative of cos⁻¹ and from d/dx(1-x²) = -2x gives us 2x/√(...), but double-checking: -1/√(...) × (-2x) = 2x/√(...). However, standard form suggests answer should be negative.

questions.question: What is d/dx(sec x - tan x)?
options: sec x tan x - sec² x
sec x tan x(1 - sec x/tan x)
questions.explanation: d/dx(sec x - tan x) = sec x tan x - sec² x = sec x tan x - sec² x. This can also be written as sec x(tan x - sec x).

questions.question: What is d/dx(sin x + cos x + tan x)?
options: cos x - sin x + sec² x
cos x + sin x + sec² x
questions.explanation: d/dx(sin x + cos x + tan x) = cos x + (-sin x) + sec² x = cos x - sin x + sec² x.

questions.question: What is d/dx(ln|sec x + tan x|)?
questions.explanation: Using chain rule: d/dx(ln|sec x + tan x|) = 1/(sec x + tan x) × (sec x tan x + sec² x) = 1/(sec x + tan x) × sec x(tan x + sec x) = sec x.
